description:
Protopterus annectens, commonly known as the West African lungfish, is a species of freshwater fish that belongs to the order Ceratodontiformes. It is one of the six extant species of lungfish, which are considered to be among the most primitive living lobe-finned fishes.

Protopterus annectens is found in West Africa, primarily in the river basins of the Gambia, Senegal, Niger, and Congo. It is a highly adapted species that can survive in a variety of aquatic habitats, including rivers, lakes, and even temporary ponds and swamps.

The West African lungfish is characterized by its elongated, eel-like body, with four slender, finger-like limbs that it uses for locomotion and anchoring itself in the substrate. It has a distinctive single lung, which allows it to breathe air and survive in low-oxygen environments, a unique adaptation that has been crucial to its survival in its often-fluctuating aquatic habitats.

These lungfish are carnivorous, feeding on a variety of small aquatic organisms, including invertebrates and other small fishes. They are known to exhibit a unique behavior of aestivating (entering a state of dormancy) during the dry season, burrowing into the mud and forming a cocoon-like structure to conserve moisture and energy.

Protopterus annectens is considered a threatened species due to various factors, including habitat loss, overfishing, and pollution. Conservation efforts are underway to protect this ancient and highly specialized fish, which is an important component of the aquatic ecosystems in West Africa.
